An Introduction to Conceptual Search
Concepts and Contexts
As humans, we tend to think conceptually. A concept can be characterized by a semantic term that represents it. Terms such as Tall, Short, Long, Early, Late, Fast, and Slow are meaningful to us because they represent concepts that we understand based on our historical experience. Let's think for a moment about the concept of tall as it relates to people. We share a common notion of what tall means, based upon our shared experience. If someone tells us a person is tall, we have a good understanding of what that means.
Let's consider some examples: Is Kareem Abdul Jabar tall? Certanly. Do you know exactly what his height is, in inches? Probably not, but we can all agree that he's tall.
Was Napolean tall? No. In fact, he's become an icon for an alternate concept: short.
Actor Brad Garrett? He's quite tall
Tom Cruise? By most measures, he is not tall.
Osama bin Laden? People agree that he was very tall.
Tall is not defined by some threshold parameter. Is someone who stands 6'8" considered tall? Sure. How 'bout someone 5'11"? Also tall. And 5'10"? We'd probably agree that yes, 5'10" is still considered tall. It may be less tall than Kareem, but still tall.
Note that there is no threshold parameter that determines tall vs not tall. Tall is a Concept, not a threshold value. This turns out to true of most all concepts, from characterizations of height to network latency to sales performance to musical talent to public sentiment.
In fact, we can graph a mathematical representation of the concept of tall. The graph in Figure 1 might be one definition of tall. Note that the X axis is Height, in inches, ranging from 48 inches to 84 inches, a fair guess at the range of heights we'd see in a large sample of humans. The Y axis depicts the degree of membership in this concept of tall. In our depection, a person who stands 60" has zero membership in the concept of tall. Someone 84" has a membership of 1, or 100%. In this scenario, an 84" person is "more tall" than a 72" person. If we were looking at the underlying fuzzy mathematics that represent our concept of tall, we'd say that 84" has 100% membership in the set tall, while 72" has a bit under 50%.
Figure 1
A question arises here. Most people would agree that, among a large sample of humans, we think of 72" as quite tall. The notion that 72" has less than 50% membership in our concept of tall doesn't seem quite right. That's OK. This just means that the straight line function we drew to represent our concept of tall is probably not a very accurate representation of the concept. We can fix that. The graph in Figure 2 is another definition of our concept of tall. This one probably comes closer to an accurate representation of what we think of, when we think of tall.

Capturing Points of View: Contexts
When we're thinking about an idea like the height of people, we consider a number of related concepts. The concepts tall and short are two "conceptually coherent" terms that describe concepts relating to height. In Extreme Search, we call this conceptually coherent grouping of concepts a context. A context defines a particular view of the world based on the meaning of the terms that define it. Such a context can be seen in Figure 3.
Figure 3
The context height in Figure 3 illustrates an important characteristic of terms within a context: that is, that terms or concepts often overlap. It it very possible for a value under analysis to have membership in more than one concept. In our example here, a person can be somewhat tall and somewhat short at the same time. This idea is true of most any context applying to most any knowledge domain. It embodies the way we, as humans, think of the world and it is an extraordinarily powerful tenent of cognitive computing.
Figure 4
Figure 4 illustrates another definition of the context height. This illustration is the display of a context called height which we've defined in Extreme Search for Splunk. Note that this context is comprised of five terms: tiny, short, typical, tall and gigantic. There's nothing particularly special about these five names. They simply have meaning to the author when describing the notion of height. They're defined by the user and represent that user's perspective with regard to the height of humans.
In Extreme Search, we allow users to define contexts either with or without regard to a particular data set. These contexts are saved in Extreme Search and can be used to analyze subsequent data sets or the same data set in a various time ranges. A subject matter expert might define a context with which the staff of his company should analyze a particular knowledge domain. For examle, a network expert might define a context called latency that support personnel or a monitoring system would use when analyzing real time network performance. If the context was generated using baseline data, applying it in real time analysis would immediately identify anomolies, without the need to learn baseline behavior. Scianta's concept-based cognitive computing engine can quickly model baseline behavior without the need for more conventional parameteric machine learning.
So this is pretty interesting. What does it get us?
Concepts and collections of them which we call Contexts are critical components in concept-based cognitive computing. They facilitate the ability to gain deep insight from your data by asking qualitative, rather than quantitative questions, and to ask those questions in natural language. Conceptual Coherence
In our example of the linear (Figure 1) vs S-shaped (Figure 2) definitions of the term tall, we noted that the shape of the membership function for a term is significant. I fact, it is important that the shape of the term represent the linguistic meaning of the term. When we say tall, the set of values that have membership in that concept should make linguistic sense. In the same way that someone would be confused if you called Karrem Abdul Jabar short and Napolean tall, they can be confused if we define concepts in Extreme Search that don't make linguistic sense. It is also important that all terms defined in a context be conceptually coherent – that they share the same "universe of discourse". It would be confusing if one term dealt with Time and another dealt with Distance. Embracing Nuance: Hedges
Concepts and Contexts are the basis of Conceptual Search but they don't, on their own, support a very nuanced view of the world. A true Cognitive Computing system, a system designed to "think" like we do, needs to understand nuance.
Scianta Extreme Search for Splunk employs the notion of "hedges" to capture nuanced variation to concepts. Hedges are linguistic modifiers, adjectives, that modify the meaning of a concept. To learn more about hedges and other methods employed by Extreme Search to embrace the nuance ot human thought, click on Learn More.
